summary: The case involved a professional model (Adegbola) who entered into a one-year contract with Insight Communications for a Starcomms TV commercial. The contract was to run from May 2005 to May 2006. After the contract expired, Starcomms continued to use the advertisement materials without renegotiating with the model. This unauthorized use led to the termination of another contract the model had with DDB Lagos Ltd worth ₦5,000,000. The main issues were whether Insight Communications acted as Starcomms' agent, and whether Starcomms had unlimited rights to use the advertising materials after the contract period. The trial court dismissed the appellant's claims, but the Court of Appeal found that Starcomms had breached the appellant's rights by using the materials without consent after the contract period, and that Insight Communications was not Starcomms' agent despite claiming to act on their behalf.
outcome: The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal and awarded the appellant ₦5,000,000 in special damages against Starcomms (2nd respondent) for wrongful breach of his right to further use of the advertisement materials. The court also awarded ₦100,000 as costs against Starcomms.
ratios: A contract in law is a legally binding agreement between two or more persons (natural and/or corporate) by which rights are acquired by one party in return for acts of consideration or forbearances, on the part of the others
Agency relationship arises from the consent, express or implied, between two parties for one to act for and on behalf of the other in regard of third parties

A party cannot alone appoint itself an agent of another in its dealing or relationship with third parties without the requisite consent or authority of the party for whom or on whose behalf the action is said to have been done

Where there was no existing valid and enforceable contract which binds the parties thereto, there cannot possibly be a maintainable allegation of breach of any terms and conditions that can sustain a claim for damages for breach of contract

precedents.name: Sha v. Kwan (2000) FWLR (Pt.11) 1798, (2000) 8 NWLR (Pt. 670) 685 at 700
precedents.context: In the case of Sha v. Kwan (2000) FWLR (Pt.11) 1798, (2000) 8 NWLR (Pt. 670) 685 at 700, it was held by the Supreme Court that:- 'The Court of Appeal is at liberty and possess the jurisdiction to modify or reject all or any of the issues formulated by the parties and frame its own issues or, as pointed out above, to reframe the issues by the parties if, in its view, such issues will not lead to proper determination of the appeal.'

precedents.name: Chabayasa v. Anwasi (2010) All FWLR (Pt. 528) 839, (2010) 10 NWLR (Pt. 1201) 163
precedents.context: Similarly, in the later case of Chabayasa v. Anwasi (2010) All FWLR (Pt. 528) 839, (2010) 10 NWLR (Pt. 1201) 163 at 181, paragraphs A-B, the apex court had restated that:- 'the law permits an appellate court to ignore some or all issues raised in the briefs of argument and formulate its own issues, the way it deems them to be material once they are distilled from the grounds of appeal.'

precedents.name: Pascutto v. Adecentro (Nig.) Ltd (1997) 11 NWLR (Pt. 529) 467
precedents.context: In the case of Pascutto v. Adecentro (Nig.) Ltd (1997) 11 NWLR (Pt. 529) 467 at 492, paragraphs 4-F, the Supreme Court has stated ways by which the relationship of principal and agent; agency in law, may arise. They are thus:- (a) by express appointment; (b) by virtue of the doctrine of estoppel; (c) by subsequent ratification by the principal of a contract made on his behalf without any authorization from the principal; (d) by implication of law in cases where it is urgently necessary that a person should act on behalf of another; and (e) by presumption of law in the case of cohabitation.

precedents.name: Vulcan Gases Ltd v. G. F. Indust. A. G. (2001) FWLR (Pt. 53) 1
precedents.context: See also the case of Vulcan Gases Ltd v. G. F. Indust. A. G. (2001) FWLR (Pt. 53) 1, (2001) 9 NWLR (Pt. 719) 610, (2001) 5 SC (Pt. 1) 1, where in addition, the apex court stated the basis of an agency relationship as follows:- 'Agency therefore, exists between two persons when one of whom expressly or impliedly consents that the other should act on his behalf so as to affect his relations with third parties, and the other of whom similarly consents to so act.'

precedents.name: Freeman & Lockyer v. Buckhurst Park Prop. (Mangal) Ltd (1964) 2 QB 480
precedents.context: The case of Freeman & Lockyer v. Buckhurst Park Prop. (Mangal) Ltd (1964) 2 QB 480, was referred to where at page 502, Diplock, LJ said:- 'An actual authority is a legal relationship between principal and agent created by a consensual agreement to which they are parties. Its scope is to be ascertained by applying ordinary principles of construction of contracts, including any proper implications from the express words used, the usage of the trade, or the course of business between the parties.'
